articles.headline: Congress Seeks to Bar Funding for U.N. Agency for Palestinians
articles.snippet: A bill would bar support for the agency, UNRWA, amid accusations that some employees were Hamas fighters. Other countries are scrambling to make up the looming shortfall.
articles.abstract: A bill would bar support for the agency, UNRWA, amid accusations that some employees were Hamas fighters. Other countries are scrambling to make up the looming shortfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States would cut off funding for the main U.N. agency that provides aid to Palestinians in Gaza under a spending agreement on track to soon become law, according to two people familiar with the plan.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon and Robert Jimison

articles.headline: Democrats Prepare Aggressive Counter to Third-Party Threats
articles.snippet: An army of lawyers aims to challenge the steadily advancing ballot-access efforts of independent candidates, who Democrats fear could peel votes away in swing states.
articles.abstract: An army of lawyers aims to challenge the steadily advancing ballot-access efforts of independent candidates, who Democrats fear could peel votes away in swing states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party, increasingly alarmed by the potential for third-party candidates to swing the election to former President Donald J. Trump, has put together a new team of lawyers aimed at tracking the threat, especially in key battleground states.

articles.headline: Taxpayers Were Overcharged for Patient Meds. Then Came the Lawyers.
articles.snippet: A group of politically connected lawyers teamed up to go after insurers and made millions from one of the largest Medicaid settlements in history.
articles.abstract: A group of politically connected lawyers teamed up to go after insurers and made millions from one of the largest Medicaid settlements in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2018, when Mike DeWine was Ohio’s attorney general, he began investigating an obscure corner of the health care industry.

articles.headline: They Thought Their Freaknik Days Were Behind Them. No, Cue the Tape.
articles.snippet: Attendees of the rowdy ’80s and ’90s-era spring festival in Atlanta are wondering whether — and how — they might show up in a new documentary about it.
articles.abstract: Attendees of the rowdy ’80s and ’90s-era spring festival in Atlanta are wondering whether — and how — they might show up in a new documentary about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back then, hundreds of thousands of young people, mostly Black college students, descended on Atlanta every spring for the rowdy and raunchy event called Freaknik. Performers like Notorious B.I.G., OutKast and Uncle Luke put on shows all over the city. The traffic hardly budged, and why should it? The party was right there in the street.

articles.headline: Reddit’s I.P.O. Is a Content Moderation Success Story
articles.snippet: The site’s journey from toxic cesspool to trusted news source illustrates the business value of keeping bad actors at bay.
articles.abstract: The site’s journey from toxic cesspool to trusted news source illustrates the business value of keeping bad actors at bay.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, no one in their right mind would have put “Reddit” and “publicly traded company” in the same sentence.

articles.headline: What Comes Next for the Housing Market?
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve still expects to cut rates this year, and a change in selling practices could shake up home shopping. Here’s the outlook.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve still expects to cut rates this year, and a change in selling practices could shake up home shopping. Here’s the outlook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are planning to cut interest rates this year, real estate agents are likely to slash their commissions after a major settlement and President Biden has begun to look for ways his administration can alleviate high housing costs.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: U.S. Sues Apple, Accusing It of Maintaining an iPhone Monopoly
articles.snippet: The lawsuit caps years of regulatory scrutiny of Apple’s wildly popular suite of devices and services, which have fueled its growth into a nearly $3 trillion public company.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit caps years of regulatory scrutiny of Apple’s wildly popular suite of devices and services, which have fueled its growth into a nearly $3 trillion public company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s aggressive crackdown on Big Tech expanded on Thursday to include an antitrust lawsuit by the Justice Department against Apple, one of the world’s best-known and most valuable companies.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Large Grocers Took Advantage of Pandemic Supply Chain Disruptions, F.T.C. Finds
articles.snippet: A report found that large firms pressured suppliers to favor them over competitors. It also concluded that some retailers “seem to have used rising costs as an opportunity to further hike prices.”
articles.abstract: A report found that large firms pressured suppliers to favor them over competitors. It also concluded that some retailers “seem to have used rising costs as an opportunity to further hike prices.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Large grocery retailers took advantage of supply chain disruptions to beat out smaller rivals and protect their profits during the pandemic, according to a report released by the Federal Trade Commission on Thursday.
